factoid: Russian troops were present in the village of Hosjeradek.

Russian troops were less disordered than before.

Everyone in the village of Hosjeradek said that the battle was lost.

Rostóv asked people in the village of Hosjeradek where Kutúzov was.

No one Rostóv asked could tell Rostóv where Kutúzov was.

Some people reported that the Emperor was not wounded.
Some people explained that the rumor that the Emperor was wounded was false.
The rumor that the Emperor was wounded spread because the Emperor’s carriage had galloped from the field of battle.
The Emperor’s carriage had galloped from the field of battle.

Ober-Hofmarschal Count Tolstóy was pale and terrified.
Ober-Hofmarschal Count Tolstóy rode out to the battlefield with others in the Emperor’s suite.
An officer told Rostóv that the officer had seen someone from headquarters behind the village to the left.
Rostóv rode to the location behind the village to the left.
Rostóv rode there not hoping to find anyone.
Rostóv rode there merely to ease Rostóv's conscience.
Rostóv rode about two miles from the village.
Rostóv passed the last of the Russian troops.
Near a kitchen garden with a ditch, Rostóv saw two men on horseback facing the ditch.
One of the men had a white plume in the man's hat.
The man with the white plume seemed familiar to Rostóv.
The other man rode a beautiful chestnut horse.
Rostóv fancied Rostóv had seen the chestnut horse before.
The man on the chestnut horse rode up to the ditch.
The man on the chestnut horse struck the man's horse with the man's spurs.
The man on the chestnut horse gave the man's horse the rein.
The man on the chestnut horse leaped lightly over the ditch.
A little earth crumbled from the bank under the horse’s hind hoofs.
The man on the chestnut horse turned the horse sharply.
The man on the chestnut horse again jumped the ditch.
Rostóv addressed the horseman with the white plume deferentially.
Rostóv suggested that the horseman with the white plume should do the same.
The rider with the white plume made a gesture of refusal with the rider's head and hand.
The gesture of refusal riveted Rostóv’s attention.
Rostóv instantly recognized the rider with the white plume as Rostóv's lamented and adored monarch.
Rostóv thought that the monarch could not be alone in the empty field.
Alexander turned Alexander's head at that moment.
Rostóv saw the beloved features of Alexander.
Alexander’s features were deeply engraved on Rostóv’s memory.
Alexander was pale.
Alexander’s cheeks were sunken.
Alexander’s eyes were hollow.
Alexander’s charm and mildness were greater.
Rostóv was happy that the rumors about Alexander being wounded were false.
Rostóv was happy to be seeing Alexander.
Rostóv knew Rostóv might go straight to Alexander.
Rostóv knew Rostóv ought to go straight to Alexander.
Rostóv had to deliver the message that Dolgorúkov had ordered Rostóv to deliver.
Rostóv was a youth in love who trembled.
Rostóv was unnerved.
Rostóv dared not utter the thoughts Rostóv had dreamed of for nights.
Rostóv looked around for help or a chance of delay and flight when the longed-for moment came.
Rostóv was alone with Alexander at that moment.
Rostóv had attained what Rostóv had longed for more than anything else in the world.
Rostóv did not know how to approach Alexander.
A thousand reasons occurred to Rostóv why it would be inconvenient to approach Alexander.
A thousand reasons occurred to Rostóv why it would be unseemly to approach Alexander.
A thousand reasons occurred to Rostóv why it would be impossible to approach Alexander.
Rostóv felt as if Rostóv were glad of a chance to take advantage of Alexander's being alone and despondent.
Rostóv believed a strange face might seem unpleasant or painful to Alexander at this moment of sorrow.

Rostóv thought Rostóv's mouth felt dry at the mere sight of Alexander.

The speeches were intended to be spoken when Rostóv was dying of wounds.

The speeches were intended to express the love Rostóv's actions had proved while dying.

Rostóv wondered how Rostóv could ask Alexander for instructions for the right flank now that the battle was lost.

Rostóv decided Rostóv must not intrude on Alexander's reflections.

Rostóv decided it was better to die a thousand times than risk receiving a bad opinion from Alexander.

Rostóv rode away with a heart full of despair.
